dublinCore.dc:title: 119 HR 2730 IH: Military Moms Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Ms. Mace (for herself, Ms. Stefanik, Mr. Wittman, and Mr. Turner of Ohio) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Armed Services

form.official-title: To include pregnancy and loss of pregnancy as qualifying life events under the TRICARE program and to require a study on maternal health in the military heath system, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Military Moms Act.

paragraph.text: The terms covered beneficiary, dependent, and TRICARE program have the meanings given those terms in section 1072 of title 10, United States Code.
The term maternal health means care during labor, birthing, prenatal care, and postpartum care.
The term maternity care desert means a county in the United States that does not have—

subparagraph.text: a hospital or birth center offering obstetric care; or
an obstetric provider.

paragraph.text: The term prenatal care means medical care provided to maintain and improve fetal and maternal health during pregnancy.
The term Secretary means the Secretary of Defense.

subsection.text: Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall—

paragraph.text: update the list of qualifying life events under the TRICARE program to include pregnancy and loss of pregnancy; and

issue guidance to covered beneficiaries describing the documentation required to make enrollment changes under the TRICARE program due to such qualifying life events, such as written confirmation from a medical provider confirming a pregnancy or loss of pregnancy.

subsection.text: This section shall not apply to a covered beneficiary who seeks to claim an abortion as a qualifying life event.

paragraph.text: The term abortion means the use or prescription of any instrument, medicine, drug, or other substance or device to intentionally—

subparagraph.text: kill the unborn child of a woman known to be pregnant; or
prematurely terminate the pregnancy of a woman known to be pregnant, with an intention other than to—

clause.text: increase the probability of a live birth or preserve the life or health of the child after a live birth;
remove a dead unborn child; or

paragraph.text: The term loss of pregnancy means miscarriage or stillbirth.

section.header: Report on access to maternal health care within the military health system

subsection.text: Not later than two years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to the Committee on Armed Services and the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate and the Committee on Armed Services and the Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives a report on access to maternal health care within the military health system for covered beneficiaries during the preceding two-year period.
The report required under subsection (a) shall include the following:

paragraph.text: With respect to military medical treatment facilities, the following:

subparagraph.text: An analysis of the availability of maternal health care for covered beneficiaries who access the military health system through such facilities.
An identification of staffing shortages in positions relating to maternal health and childbirth, including obstetrician-gynecologists, certified nurse midwives, and labor and delivery nurses.
A description of specific challenges faced by covered beneficiaries in accessing maternal health care at such facilities.
An analysis of the timeliness of access to maternal health care, including wait times for and travel times to appointments.
A description of how such facilities track patient satisfaction with maternal health services.
A process to establish continuity of prenatal care and postpartum care for covered beneficiaries who experience a permanent change of station during a pregnancy.
An identification of barriers with regard to continuity of prenatal care and postpartum care during permanent changes of station.

A description of military-specific health challenges impacting covered beneficiaries who receive maternal health care at military medical treatment facilities, and a description of how the Department tracks such challenges.
For the 10-year period preceding the date of the submission of the report, the amount of funds annually expended—

clause.text: by the Department of Defense on maternal health care; and
by covered beneficiaries on out-of-pocket costs associated with maternal health care.

subparagraph.text: An identification of each medical facility of the Department of Defense located in a maternity care desert.
Recommendations and legislative proposals—

clause.text: to address staffing shortages that impact the positions described in subparagraph (B);
to improve the delivery and availability of maternal health services through military medical treatment facilities and improve patient experience; and
to improve continuity of prenatal care and postpartum care for covered beneficiaries during a permanent change of station.

paragraph.text: With respect to providers within the TRICARE program network that are not located at or affiliated with a military medical treatment facility, the following:

subparagraph.text: An analysis of the availability of maternal health care for covered beneficiaries who access the military health system through such providers.

An identification of staffing shortages for such providers in positions relating to maternal health and childbirth, including obstetrician-gynecologists, certified nurse midwives, and labor and delivery nurses.
A description of specific challenges faced by covered beneficiaries in accessing maternal health care from such providers.
An analysis of the timeliness of access to maternal health care, including wait times for and travel times to appointments.
A description of how such providers track patient satisfaction with maternal health services.
A process to establish continuity of prenatal care and postpartum care for covered beneficiaries who experience a permanent change of station during a pregnancy.
An identification of barriers with regard to continuity of prenatal care and postpartum care during permanent changes of station.
The number of dependents who choose to access maternal health care through such providers.
For the 10-year period preceding the date of the submission of the report, the amount of funds annually expended—

clause.text: by the Department of Defense on maternal health care; and
by covered beneficiaries on out-of-pocket costs associated with maternal health care.

subparagraph.text: Recommendations and legislative proposals—

clause.text: to address staffing shortages that impact the positions described in subparagraph (B);
to improve the delivery and availability of maternal health services through the TRICARE program and improve patient experience;
to improve continuity of prenatal care and postpartum care for covered beneficiaries during a permanent change of station; and

to improve the ability of contractors under the TRICARE program to build a larger network of providers for maternal health, including obstetrician-gynecologists, certified nurse midwives, and labor and delivery nurses.

subsection.text: Not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall publish on a publicly available website of the Military OneSource program of the Department of Defense a dedicated webpage that includes a comprehensive guide of resources available to covered beneficiaries, including—

paragraph.text: a list of maternal health services that are available to covered beneficiaries under the TRICARE program and at military medical treatment facilities;
information on mental health counseling, pregnancy counseling, and other prepartum and postpartum services, including what services are reportable or non-reportable for members of the Armed Forces;
information on prenatal development, including anticipated prenatal appointments and available care for covered beneficiaries during prenatal development;

subparagraph.text: organizations that provide services and other resources to assist covered beneficiaries with maternal health needs and pregnancy support services located at, or in vicinity of, military installations; and
Federal, State, and local maternal health care resources that are either covered by the TRICARE program or could otherwise be made available to a covered beneficiary;

paragraph.text: information on resources to assist covered beneficiaries who are pregnant with anticipated changes and health challenges that result from pregnancy, including information on anticipated postnatal appointments, available postnatal care for covered beneficiaries, and post-birth instructions specific to covered beneficiaries;
information on financial assistance available to covered beneficiaries to support pregnancy needs;
a best practice guide for smooth continuity of pregnancy care during a permanent change of station; and

information specific to pregnant members of the Armed Forces, including leave options and regulations, career field specific information and restrictions, physical fitness requirements, and uniform resources and requirements.

subsection.text: The guide required by subsection (a) may not include information, references, or resources on abortion.

The Secretary shall provide training to military and family life counselors available through the Military OneSource program on addressing the non-medical needs of covered beneficiaries who are pregnant.
The Secretary shall notify the head of the Military OneSource program when a covered beneficiary makes the Secretary aware of a pregnancy.

Not later than 540 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall develop and submit to Congress a plan for the Secretary to disseminate to beneficiaries of the Military OneSource program the guide required by subsection (a).
